messages: 37d2de30a27c46d835b1351ae69ab8be (20:15): how do I delete obsolete datafilecopy entries in rman?
37d2de30a27c46d835b1351ae69ab8be (20:16): they don't show up in 'list backupset summary', but they do show up in 'list datafilecopy all'.  I deleted the actual files a long time ago.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (20:17): rizzo: delete noprompt obsolete device type disk;
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (20:18): skip noprompt btw :)
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (20:18): it may be a bit dangerous
37d2de30a27c46d835b1351ae69ab8be (20:18): yeah that lists my recent backups as well
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (20:18): set the retention policy in rman to get the correct files
37d2de30a27c46d835b1351ae69ab8be (20:19): What I'm aiming for is that it would sense that the datafiles are no longer on disk
37d2de30a27c46d835b1351ae69ab8be (20:19): so it should want to remove the entries from RMAN
37d2de30a27c46d835b1351ae69ab8be (20:20): I know it did this with backupsets
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (20:20): you should let rman delete the files.. not os commands
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (20:20): to keep everything "in sync"
37d2de30a27c46d835b1351ae69ab8be (20:23): ok I set retention policy to 7 days
37d2de30a27c46d835b1351ae69ab8be (20:23): it only showed me backupsets from Jul 10-16
37d2de30a27c46d835b1351ae69ab8be (20:24): there are datafilecopy entries from 27-JUN that I want to get rid of, they still show up in 'list datafilecopy all'
6c485faf792dbf2f15b681b53dcf7516 (20:42): anyone is up
673f57c9d72f58924c64aa80ccaa12da (20:46): sys.dbms_transaction....?
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:10): hi, anyone around?

2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:14): this person is telling me there is some sort of method that tells this oracle database to load a bunch of data into memory.  From what I understand I thought Oracle managed this automatically.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:15): you can hint it to load a table in to memory
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:15): alter table cache;
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:15): which will suggest to oracle that it may be a good idea to load it in to memory
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:15): "which puts the database tables (from disk) into RAM. "
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:16): he is telling me some code of ours is telling oracle to do this.
3f80d62ed949f29a551f0f7d97ab8089 (21:16): Mr_You, You can use a KEEP buffer
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:16): it puts a HUGE hit on the database.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:16): alter table storage (buffer_pool keep); .. but it shouldn't be abused for all tables you think should be cached
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:17): this is the scenario... db is updated, they run a script which nails the database causing it to "put this stuff in memory" which then the DB changes show up.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:17): oracle is quite good when it comes to the automatic stuff
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:17): especially in 10g
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:17): yeah which is why I'm confused.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:17): it's a typical burelson thing
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:17): whats that mean?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:18): donald burlesson has a professional dba consuntancy... he thinks he's the king of everything oracle related
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:18): he likes to make up cool stories so he can get consuntancy time to go to client sites and spend a few hours "tuning"
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:19): like rebuilding indexes ever 6 hours
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:19): I think I've seen that site.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:20): burlesson suggest to have a batch job on the db server to "identify" all tables that "have to be" in the keep pool... and automaticly buffer then
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:20): in this case, the changes aren't being seen til they run this script, who knows what they are doing/why... its a bunch of crap code.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:20): i love it when tom kyte talkes about burlesson

2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:21): I'm wondering if they aren't committing changes until the script is ran and maybe for some dumb reason, the script is nailing the database to make up for some crap that happened in the past.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:21): i mean its not a bad idea to actually put tables in the keep pool
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:22): this has existed since Oracle 8?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:22): no idea... at least since 8
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:22): ok
3f80d62ed949f29a551f0f7d97ab8089 (21:25): hali, there is quote about Burleson?)
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:25): http://asktom.oracle.com/pls/ask/f?p=4950:8:17753972428972245717::NO::F4950_P8_DISPLAYID,F4950_P8_CRITERIA:2913600659112
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:25): search for "scientist"
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:25): I'm sure DB is an "expert" based on the definition:
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:25): - experts CLAIM things
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:25): - scientists PROVE things
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:25): DB being donald burlesson :)
f539ea771a63f006a2b9adf2f340fc1d (21:40): hello
eb93047c765621b93e71a96ce11ca262 (21:54): good evening... guick question: is there nay easy way to determine why an oracle insance is bogged down in a write operations and what is causing them?
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:57): hali: heh
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (21:57): hali: it seems that we might be using temp tables improperly.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:59): improper temp usage?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (21:59): i've seen that ... where temp just grows and grows
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:01): in this case they are creating temp tables to put things in RAM.
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:02): from what I understand.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:02): im not sure i follow
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:02): thats just weird
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:02): they do a lot of weird crap
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:03): err.. weird or umm... plain stupid.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:03): to get easier access to processed data?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:03): i can understand if they create materialized views to get faster access to processed data
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:03): "easier" access to static data from what I understand.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:03): that could make sense
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:04): well, if there is a performance benefit.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:04): but i would never use temp tables.. materialized views do exactly that.. and you can even schedule it to update automaticly
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:04): but right now having to update the TEMP table puts a huge hit on the db.
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:04): yeah
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:04): if it is based on a semi-slow query and there is no need for realtime data
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:04): not sure.  Either way it doesn't sound right to me.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:05): but you get the view log overhead on the tables under it.. but that should be close to neglitable
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:05): at least if you want fast refresh, which im pretty sure you do :)
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:05): this is something thats always been there since they use to use 8.1.5 ... its just been moved to 10g.
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:06): this place is a joke, I gotta find something else.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:07): or do a hostile takeover
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:08): lock yourself in the server room with a big gun
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:08): I've been attempting that.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:08): and tell them to sort it out
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:08): they just don't get it AT ALL.
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:08): there is zero real management here.
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:08): new people are leaving.
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:08): or have left.
2fcc1af54942f1bdefc18f4e88f2ac7c (22:09): the only people that stay are those lucky enough just to have a job in this field.
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:09): hate those
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (22:09): anyway. im off... l8er
